docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re Paul Krugman's July 16 column, ''The Waiting Game'':

headline.main: Look to Congress On Health Care

docs.abstract: Two letters comment on July 16 Paul Krugman column about Pres Bush's intent to veto bipartisan health care plan; Jack E Cohen asks why all Americans do not have same great health care plan that members of Congress enjoy; Dr Brian F Keaton (American College of Emergency Physicians) says safety net of emergency departments for health care is breaking under heavy load

docs.lead_paragraph: The head of the Department of Veterans Affairs resigned after serving two and a half years marred by budget shortfalls and the theft of personal data.

headline.main: V.A. Chief to Step Down, Citing Return to Private Life
headline.print_headline: V.A. Chief To Step Down, Citing Return To Private Life

docs.snippet: The head of the Department of Veterans Affairs resigned after serving two and a half years marred by budget shortfalls and the theft of personal data.

docs.lead_paragraph: Workers who say that toxic dust from the World Trade Center site has given them serious health problems filed a lawsuit yesterday against an insurance fund set up by Congress to insure the city and its contractors after the Sept 11 attack. The lawsuit, filed in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, is seeking compensation from the fund, WTC Captive Insurance Company, on behalf of thousands of workers who became ill after working to clean up the site. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the workers’ lawyers were incorrect about the purpose of the fund. The mayor said the insurance fund could pay only workers who win judgments against the city. “The truth of the matter is, Congress didn’t set up a victims’ compensation fund,” the mayor said.

headline.main: Manhattan: 9/11 Cleanup Workers Seek Health Payments
headline.print_headline: Manhattan: 9/11 Cleanup Workers Seek Health Payments

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton aimed her fire today at President Bush, saying that from the first day of his administration he began rolling back various programs and funding avenues that had supported abortion rights. She cited limits he imposed on foreign assistance to certain international groups, which became known as the "global gag rule;" programs promoting abstinence-only education in schools; and the appointment of Supreme Court justices who, she said, have chipped away at Roe v. Wade.

headline.main: Clinton Takes Her Turn at Planned Parenthood Event

docs.abstract: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton blamed President Bush for rolling back abortion rights during his administration, and pledged to take a dramatically different course if she won the presidency.
docs.snippet: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton blamed President Bush for rolling back abortion rights during his administration, and pledged to take a dramatically different course if she won the presidency.

docs.lead_paragraph: The top story of the day is the State Legislature's decision to shelve Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's congestion pricing proposal for now, dealing a possibly fatal blow to the mayor's signature environmental and transportation initiative. As Danny Hakim and Nicholas Confessore report, the action -- or lack thereof -- by the two chambers of the Legislature came after a day of frantic last-minute efforts by the mayor to revive the plan. Talks continued late into the night, and no one was willing to pronounce the congestion pricing proposal dead.

headline.main: Morning Buzz: Congestion Pricing Shelved; Transcript Fraud; Albany Fund-Raising; and More

docs.lead_paragraph: Many migrant workers are bringing AIDS to rural parts of Mexico, which are not prepared to handle the epidemic.

headline.print_headline: Mexican Migrants Carry H.I.V. Home to Unready Rural Areas
